headline: Transforming Lancashire County Council
tagline: From inherited chaos to fiscal discipline — Reform UK's first year in control

inherited_problems.operation_sheridan: Former leader Geoff Driver awaiting criminal trial

items.label: Projected overspend eliminated in 8 months
items.detail: Inherited £28M projected overspend reduced to £6.1M at Q3 (January 2026). S151 Officer confirmed budget monitoring mitigations working. Balanced budget approved by Full Council 26 Feb 2026.

items.label: Savings identified by efficiency review
items.detail: Cabinet-approved efficiency review completed November 2025 identified £22M savings over 3 years across contracts, procurement, property and digital

items.label: Savings delivery target for 2025/26
items.detail: Targeting 100% delivery of £60M savings — compared to the Conservatives' 48% delivery rate the previous year

items.label: Agency staff spending reduction
items.detail: Agency staffing costs tracking £1.5M below levels from 12 months prior

items.label: Debt reduction plan over 5 years
items.detail: Council debt of £1.181B targeted to reduce to £1.056B by 2030/31

council_tax.headline: Lowest Council Tax Rise in 12 Years

items.label: Reform's council tax rise (2026/27)
items.detail: 1.8% core + 2.0% adult social care precept — the lowest rise in Lancashire in 12 years

items.label: Conservatives' rise (2025/26)
items.detail: The maximum allowed without a referendum — applied for the second consecutive year

items.label: Highest ever under Conservatives (2018/19)
items.detail: The Conservatives raised council tax to the maximum in 7 of their 8 years in control

items.label: Paper loss on VeLTIP bond portfolio
items.detail: Reform exposed that £519M invested in the VeLTIP bond portfolio had a current value of only £169M — a paper loss of approximately £350M concealed under the previous Conservative administration

items.label: Original investment
items.detail: Invested in a bond portfolio under the Lancashire County Pension Fund

items.label: Current estimated value
items.detail: The true scale of the loss was not transparently reported to councillors or the public under the previous administration

items.label: Councillors' paid directorships on LCC pension fund companies ended
items.detail: Reform stopped Councillors receiving tens of thousands of pounds in salaries for being directors of the LCC pension fund companies (including Local Pensions Partnership Ltd), a practice under the previous Conservative administration. Cllr Alan Schofield served as a paid director and shareholder representative until Reform took control in May 2025.

items.label: National DOGE team advisory support
items.detail: The national Reform DOGE team has been providing remote support on bond valuations and pension fund fee structures — described as 'a key piece of work that will save council taxpayers a lot of money'

items.label: Residential homes protected despite £50M savings pressure
items.detail: After years of underinvestment, Reform inherited a consultation process already in the pipeline. They listened to 1,600+ residents and saved all five care homes, pledging new investment — despite inheriting a £50M savings requirement from the previous administration

items.label: Annual adult social care budget
items.detail: The largest single budget area — consuming over 40% of the council's net revenue budget

items.label: ASC savings delivered 2025/26
items.detail: Living Better Lives in Lancashire transformation programme delivering savings while maintaining frontline services

items.label: Saved by freezing all councillor allowances
items.detail: Reform led a near-unanimous vote (75-0, 3 abstentions) to reject all proposed councillor pay rises and the proposed £1,000 SRA for opposition members

items.label: Allowance increase for Reform councillors
items.detail: While other councils awarded increases, Reform councillors at LCC took no pay rise whatsoever

items.label: Productivity gain targeted through AI
items.detail: Rather than hiring 285 new staff for SEND and adult social care backlogs, AI automation will cover the productivity gap

items.label: 2025-2029 digital transformation programme
items.detail: Cognitive Search Copilot rollout, generative AI proof-of-concepts, automated social worker paperwork, AI-powered highways management

items.label: Real-time traffic signal optimisation
items.detail: AI tool using historical and real-time data to forecast network conditions, override traffic signals, and pre-empt congestion

items.label: Reduction in road defects in first 6 months
items.detail: Tens of thousands of road defects completed through proactive, data-driven approach

items.label: Dedicated pothole and structural repair budget
items.detail: Plus an additional £5M emergency cabinet decision for responsive patching, resurfacing, and road markings

items.label: 3-year roads investment pledge
items.detail: Systematic investment replacing the previous administration's reactive approach

items.label: SEND pupil places created (277 in 2025 + 400 announced)
items.detail: Including a new 200+ pupil special school to be built by 2027

items.label: Additional investment in Educational Psychology
items.detail: Addressing chronic underfunding inherited from previous administration

items.label: EHCP applications digitised
items.detail: Online portal procured, built, tested and rolling out from September 2025 — replacing paper-based system
